children.subject: I'm not sure why you put both CS, and eecs. Are you L&S CS or EECS? or something else ..?
The answer depends on what major you are.
CS61C and 70 are generally easy to get into for cs majors and eecs majors. Almost all my friends who were on the waitlist of these classes last semester got into them in the end.

For CS70, sp15 was only hard to get in because so many students were avoiding Sahai in fa14 (or at least, I assume that's why fa14 had a hundred fewer students than average, and sp15 had a hundred more than expected). It's not generally a problem.

This is a toughie. 61C and 70 are variable. This applies if you are LSCS more so than EECS, because EECS has reserved seats and it is generally not an issue to get into these classes.

When I took 61C in Fall 2014 (Garcia), there was literally JUST enough room to fit everyone after dropping. That is, there were around 2 spots left unfilled. Given current enrollment trends, I'm not sure if that will change or not, depending on the instructor.

When I took 70 in Spring 2015 (Vazirani), there was an enormous demand, and anyone who didn't Phase I the class had practically no chance of getting in. While they did end up expanding the class a little, many students still did not get in.

As for Physics 7A, there is no waitlist, so if it fills up, you're either stuck with not taking it, or checking back regularly to see if someone dropped. ESPM 50AC certainly must be used for Phase I units, because it fills up quickly*.

*This is from observing multiple of my friends and classmates taking it, not from personal experience.

history.content: I'm a first-year EECS major and I'm planning to take cs 61c, cs 70, physics 7a, and espm 50ac for the sophomore fall semester. Does anyone have advice about what I should phase 1 vs. phase 2? cs 61c and cs 70 are obviously the most important classes for me to get into, but I don't know if I can reliably get them for phase 2 so I can phase 1 the other classes.
history.subject: Phase 1 vs. 2: CS 61C, CS70, Physics 7a, ESPM 50ac
